channel.title: Bloomberg Markets
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Mastercard's Meyer Talks Retail and Travel Trends
item.description: Mastercard Economics Institute Chief Economist Michelle Meyer says retailers are still seeing an engaged consumer and there's no clear evidence yet that tariffs are playing a role in spending on "Bloomberg The Close." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Gold Holds Decline as US Government Debt, Dollar Make Gains
item.description: Gold steadied after its first decline this week, as some traders turned to long-term US government bonds and the dollar instead of the precious metal.
item.dc:creator: Jason Scott

media:content.media:description: An employee arranges gold bars at the Italpreziosi SpA precious metals refinery plant in Arezzo, Italy, on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. Gold fell, snapping a two-day advance, as signs of progress on US-China trade talks curbed demand for havens even as military hostilities between India and Pakistan escalated.

item.title: Asian Stocks to Rise as Dollar, Treasuries Rebound: Markets Wrap
item.description: Asian equity futures edged higher Friday amid a rebound in Treasuries and the dollar in a sign of calming US fiscal fears that rocked markets earlier in the week. US stocks were little changed.
item.dc:creator: Richard Henderson

item.title: Former Sunnova CEO Calls End to Tax Credits Un-American
item.description: Former Sunnova Energy CEO John Berger says the US House Republicans’ new version of the tax and spending bill that accelerates the end of incentives for clean energy production is “patently unfair and un-American” on “Bloomberg The Close.”

item.title: Lagarde Says International Trade Will Never Be the Same Again
item.description: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde warned that international trade will be changed forever by the tensions over tariffs, even as the world’s leading economies edge toward some compromises.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde, president of the European Central Bank (ECB), speaks at 'The Transformative Power of AI: Economic Implications and Challenges' conference in Frankfurt, Germany, on Tuesday, April 1, 2025. Euro-area inflation eased further toward the European Central Bank’s 2% target as officials weigh whether or not to continue lowering interest rates.

item.title: Bitcoin Rally Pushes Biggest Token Further Into Record Territory
item.description: Bitcoin surpassed $111,000 for the first time, with traders increasingly bullish on the prospects of the original cryptocurrency amid mounting institutional demand and support from Donald Trump’s administration.
item.dc:creator: Suvashree Ghosh, Sidhartha Shukla

media:content.media:description: A Bitcoin logo inside a cryptocurrency exchange in Barcelona, Spain, on Wednesday, March 9, 2022. Bitcoin dropped back below $40,000, erasing almost all the gains sparked by optimism about U.S. President Joe Biden’s executive order to put more focus on the crypto sector.

item.title: Goldman Accuses 1MDB Banker of ‘Serial Lies’ Ahead of Sentencing
item.description: Goldman Sachs Group Inc. said the banker at the heart of a scandal linked to Malaysia’s 1MDB investment fund engaged in “serial lies” and deception about the fraud, days before he is scheduled to be sentenced.
item.dc:creator: Todd Gillespie, Patricia Hurtado

media:content.media:description: Tim Leissner, former chairman of Southeast Asia for Goldman Sachs Group Inc., center, departs from federal court in the Brooklyn borough of New York, U.S., on Tuesday, Feb. 15, 2022. Ng is accused of conspiring to violate U.S. anti-money-laundering law in a scheme to loot billions from the Malaysian fund known as 1MDB.

item.title: Realtor.com Economist Hale on Home Sales, Mortgage Rates
item.description: Realtor.com Chief Economist Danielle Hale reacts to the drop in US existing-home sales and discusses recent housing market trends on “Bloomberg The Close.” US sales of previously owned homes unexpectedly dropped in April to the slowest pace in seven months.

item.title: Stocks Lose Steam in Final Minutes of US Trading: Markets Wrap
item.description: Wall Street struggled to regain confidence in the wake of a Treasury selloff that shook markets amid fiscal concerns, with stocks dropping in the last stretch of US trading. Bonds and the dollar rose.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

item.title: Real Sells Off as Brazil Taxes Remittances to Shore Up Budget
item.description: Brazil will freeze 31 billion reais ($5.5 billion) in spending and raise a tax on financial transactions in a bid to assuage investors increasingly skeptical of President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva’s fiscal promises.
item.dc:creator: Martha Viotti Beck, Felipe Saturnino

media:content.media:description: A customer withdraws Brazilian real banknotes at an automated teller machine (ATM) in Sao Paulo, Brazil, on Tuesday, Dec. 17, 2024. Brazil's central bank sold more than $3 billion on the spot market Tuesday but failed to stem a currency selloff that is fueling inflation in Latin America's largest economy.

item.title: Target’s Troubles Leave Analysts Most Negative Since 2018
item.description: Wall Street’s enthusiasm for Target Corp. is at its lowest in more than six years, as disappointing earnings from the big-box retailer spur a series of analyst downgrades.
item.dc:creator: Joel Leon

media:content.media:description: Shoppers walk towards a Target store in New York.

item.title: Stock Close Mixed After Choppy Session | Closing Bell
item.description: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Scarlet Fu, Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: S&P 500 Notches Third Day of Declines as Rally Loses Steam
item.description: A comeback failed to materialize for Wall Street on Thursday as a rally in stocks lost momentum in the final minutes of trading.
item.dc:creator: Joel Leon

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Wednesday, April 9, 2025. US equity futures extended declines on Wednesday with the S&P 500 Index trading on the brink of a bear market as China retaliated against the US and further raised tariffs on American goods.

item.title: Telecom Argentina Debt Sale Defies Telefonica Deal Scrutiny
item.description: Telecom Argentina SA tapped international debt markets following its acquisition of Telefonica SA’s local unit, a deal that has stoked fierce opposition from President Javier Milei’s government.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Simauchi

media:content.media:description: The building housing the corporate headquarters of Telecom Argentina SA is seen in Buenos Aires.

item.title: Barry Ritholtz on How Not to Invest
item.description: Admit when your unsure and don’t mix investing with politics. In this episode of Trillions, longtime money manager Barry Ritholtz dishes on what to avoid.
item.dc:creator: Joel Weber, Eric Balchunas

media:content.media:description: Barry Ritholtz, chief executive officer at FusionIQ, speaks during an interview in New York, U.S., on Monday, March 5, 2012. Fusion IQ is a comprehensive equity and group ranking system that fuses technical and fundamental metrics.

item.title: Bloomberg Markets 05/22/2025
item.description: "Bloomberg Markets" follows the market moves across every global asset class and discusses the biggest issues for Wall Street. Today's guests are Principal Asset Management Chief Global Strategist Seema Shah, Columbia Threadneedle Global Rates Strategist Ed Al-Hussainy, CFTC Commissioner Summer Mersinger, Morgan Stanley Analyst Simeon Gutman. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Fannie, Freddie Shares Surge as Trump Again Floats Privatization
item.description: A proposal by President Donald Trump to privatize Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac after almost two decades under government control has the mortgage companies’ stock prices leaping to their highest levels in 16 years.
item.dc:creator: Norah Mulinda, Yiqin Shen

media:content.media:description: The Freddie Mac headquarters in Mclean, Virginia.

item.title: Hinge Health Jumps 17% After Top-Priced $437 Million IPO
item.description: Hinge Health Inc. shares rose 17% after the digital physical therapy provider and a group of investors raised $437 million in an initial public offering priced at the top of a marketed range.
item.dc:creator: Carmen Reinicke, Anthony Hughes

media:content.media:description: Hinge Health signage outside the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) during the company's initial public offering (IPO) in New York, US, on Thursday, May 21, 2025. Hinge Health Inc. and a group of investors raised $437 million in the digital physical therapy provider's US initial public offering, pricing shares at the top of a marketed range.

item.title: Ryan Reynolds’ MNTN Shares Rise 65% After $187 Million IPO
item.description: Connected TV advertising platform MNTN Inc.’s shares climbed 65% after the company and some of its shareholders raised $187 million in an initial public offering.
item.dc:creator: Carmen Reinicke, Anthony Hughes

item.title: Anthropic Announces Claude Opus 4, Sonnet 4
item.description: Anthropic is set to roll out two new versions of its Claude artificial intelligence software, including a long-delayed update to its high-end Opus model, as the startup vies to stay ahead of a crowded market. Bloomberg's Ed Ludlow has more. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: 2025 Qatar Economic Forum Day Three Highlights
item.description: Highlights from day three of the 2025 Qatar Economic Forum, Powered by Bloomberg. International CEOs share unique perspectives on how technology and AI are transforming the global economy in Doha, Qatar. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Long-Term Bond Yields Soar Globally on Fiscal Policy Fears
item.description: From the US to Japan, long-term borrowing costs for the world’s biggest economies have surged as investors question the ability of governments to cover massive budget deficits.
item.dc:creator: Alice Gledhill, Mia Glass

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC.

item.title: G-7 Warns of ‘Excessive Imbalances’ in Global Economy
item.description: Finance ministers and central bank governors from the Group of Seven nations pledged to address “excessive imbalances” in the global economy, an effort clearly aimed at China, though the final communique omitted the name of the country.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Jorge Valero, Erik Hertzberg, William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, during a House Financial Services Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Bessent said he’s working with US legislators on outbound investment rules for China that would make clear what’s allowed and what’s not.

item.title: Bond Investors Threaten Popular Hedge-Fund Bet on Swap Spreads
item.description: A surge in long-term bond yields is once again threatening to upend a crowded hedge-fund bet that Treasuries will perform better than interest-rate swaps.
item.dc:creator: Edward Bolingbroke

item.title: Platinum Steadies Near One-Year High as Market Weighs Shortage
item.description: Platinum hovered around a one-year high as traders weighed ongoing deficits against an uncertain demand outlook.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ryan

item.title: Trump’s Fannie, Freddie Pitch: Who Stands to Win or Lose
item.description: President Donald Trump’s announcement that he’s weighing a public offering of US mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac sent their shares soaring, extending gains this year for hedge funds and other investors to almost $50 billion.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Wong, Prashant Gopal, Norah Mulinda

media:content.media:description: Prospective buyers attend an open house at a home in San Francisco.

item.title: Japan Could Ask State-Owned Firms to Buy Bonds, Barclays Says
item.description: Japan may consider asking government-owned entities to support the nation’s bond market if the selloff in longer-dated debt doesn’t abate, according to Barclays Plc’s global chair of research.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ritchie

media:content.media:description: A post box outside a Japan Post Co. branch in Tokyo.

item.title: Trump Crypto Involvement Good for Industry: Bitwise
item.description: Trump’s involvement in the crypto industry has been helpful despite concerns about a pay-to-play environment created by his memecoin, says Katherine Dowling, general counsel for Bitwise. Dowling tells Bloomberg’s Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow that lawmakers should look past the "political noise" and push for crypto legislation. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oil Falls to Lowest in Two Weeks as OPEC+ Weighs Output Surge
item.description: Oil fell to its lowest settling price in almost two weeks as US stockpiles gained and OPEC+ members discussed another major production increase, just as demand faces headwinds from the US-led trade war.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Charleston

media:content.media:description: The Deer Park Complex oil refinery and petrochemical plant, owned by Petroleos Mexicanos (PEMEX), in Houston, Texas, US, on Saturday, March 8, 2025. Some 40% of the crude oil processed at US refineries is imported, and Canada and Mexico, the No. 1 and No. 2 foreign suppliers of oil to the US, respectively, together deliver more than two-thirds of that oil. Photographer: Mark Felix/Bloomberg

item.title: Hinge Health Goes Public, Raising $437M for Investors
item.description: Hinge Health CEO Dan Perez says the company’s IPO proves Hinge held up its end of the bargain for investors. Perez discusses plans for growth and attracting new users with Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on "Bloomberg Technology." (Source: Bloomberg)
